italo_lombards.name: Italo Lombards (775-1100 AD)
italo_lombards.description: The northern Lombard-Italian kingdom was conquered in 774 by the Carolingian Franks. It would over time be folded into what became the Holy Roman Empire. Northern Italia had the independent duchy of Spoleto. Southern Italia included the independent duchies of Benevento and Amalfi, along with the independent principalities of Capua and Salerno. The  remaining independent Italo-Lombards in the southern fell to the Sicilian-Normans/Italo-Normans by 1077.
italo_lombards.gameplay_tips: WAB: GG suggests this faction have a 1 to 1 ratio of heavy to medium cavalry, with more experianced warriors being at least half. However, unlike the other kingdoms of it's period, it suggests up to half can be Liberi and Coloni. Only the Flemish have better infantry, while this faction has perfectly good cavalry options.
italo_lombards.design_notes: This might need to be split into the North and South Italo-Lombards due to the latters ability to access Norman mercenaries and not other kinds that north Italia could access

early_hre.name: Early Holy Roman Empire (900-1100 AD)
early_hre.description: Otto the Great founded his own 'Ottonian dynasty'(Technically his father, Conrad, started the dynasty), finally seperating the Eastern, German portion of the old Holy Roman Empire from the Franks/French.

burgundy.name: Various Kingdoms of Burgundy (900-1033 AD)
burgundy.description: The region of Burgundy would divide and unite over and over during this period before being conquered by the Holy Roman Empire.

coloni_skirm.name: Coloni Skirmishers
coloni_skirm.description: A band of the impoverished and landless men who could only bring the clothes on their back, a short blade or club, and some ranged weapons. These 'Coloni' were fond of the bow, but generally used any ranged weapon that would prevent them from having to fight in melee. This was a common fate of people called to service, but incredibly poor, extending all the way back to the Republican Romans.

models.name: Lowborn
models.notes: LK, The Aachen capitulary contained a further provision that no soldier should carry a cudgel (baculum), but rather a bow. It's often assumed this provision applies to free peasants of impoverished or middling means

light_tribal_warriors.name: Light Tribal Warriors
light_tribal_warriors.description: As the Germanic Cultures conquered other peoples and tribes, expanding their armies, some of these people fought as allies or subordinants before they had fully been assimilated or abandoned. The Gepids and Lombards included Saxons and Slavs in some of their armies.

tribal_warriors.name: Tribal Warriors
tribal_warriors.description: As the Germanic Cultures conquered other peoples and tribes, expanding their armies, some of these people fought as allies or subordinants before they had fully been assimilated or abandoned. The Gepids and Lombards included Saxons and Slavs in some of their armies.

comitatus.name: Comitatus
comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

shield_mount_comitatus.name: Shielded and Mounted Comitatus
shield_mount_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

mount_comitatus.name: Mounted Comitatus
mount_comitatus.description: There was many different words for personal guards and retinues of powerful nobles, such as for lords or even a king. They were just as skilled as fighting on foot and on horseback, and were similar to the 'honor guard' units of other cultures. The latin term 'Comitatus' (Retainer), is used to refer to the general concept of such loyal warriors.

rich_mount_franci.name: Merchant Militia
rich_mount_franci.description: The southern areas of Gaul/Francia, along with the northern areas of Italia, were wealthier and retained more elements of Romano-Gallo civilization. The trading ports and merchant towns of these areas could produce wealthy nobles, with vested self-interest in maintaining the current political order.

models.name: Franci
models.notes: Carol Cav Osprey states source that indicates this existed.

mount_franci.name: Mounted Franci
mount_franci.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those with more money and resources.

franci.name: Franci
franci.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those with more money and resources.

drilled_italo_franci.name: Drilled Italian Town Militia
drilled_italo_franci.description: Italia was one of the most urbanized and wealthy parts of Europe, and the townsfolk provided fairly reasonable militia. This unit can also represent a well-practiced rural/village milita of middle class landowners 'Liberi'

models.name: Liberi
models.notes: WAB: GG suggests for this unit to exist. There should be only one for every 500 points.

italian_militia.name: Italian Communal Militia
italian_militia.description: While northern Italy had plenty of reasonable or even good spear militia, the poorer or less trained members of its militia armies were meager.

models.name: Milita
models.notes: TTS&ADLG, along with WAB:FS:HRE states this unit should be here. ADLG says its not just city or towns, but also villages or rural areas.

saxon_cavalry.name: Saxon/Thuringian Cavalry
saxon_cavalry.description: Among the Germanic subjects were those not wealthy enough to be 'warrior nobility' (Knights), but with the money to afford a horse and kit like a Franci, and the eagerness to fight like a Saxon warrior.

liberi.name: Liberi
liberi.description: Previously known as 'Franci', the Liberi (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

later_freemen.name: Freemen Milita
later_freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

archer_freemen.name: Freemen Archer Milita
archer_freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

mounted_freemen.name: Mounted Freemen
mounted_freemen.description: The franci (Latin) were the landowning class, some with enough money to afford a horse, but with most just having enough to have at least decent equipment. This unit represents those who had less land and resources, but still could support themselves and show up with the basics.

foot_italian_milites.name: Dismounted Lombard Gasindi
foot_italian_milites.description: The Gasindi (Companions) were feudal vassals of the Lombard king. Because they served a similar role as the 'milites' (Latin for ''soldier''), it is possible that they were sometimes referred to as such, or that they served alongside such types of warriors. These vassals often fought on horseback, as had increasingly been the tradition and focus of the Lombards over the previous few hundred years. While the gasindi would evolve into the 'knights' of later periods, the Lombards are different from the Franks in that the Lombards had a longer history of fighting with the cavalry spear.

models.name: Gasindio
models.notes: (Quad LkI) WAB: GG uses the term milites. TtS uses 'nobles and gasindii'. The WAB:AoA2 and Total War: ATTILA - Age of Charlemagne both messed up and used the term gastald/o to refer to warrior nobility at the rank of a knight or milites. Some wargaming miniature companies use this term instead and it's definition seems more appropriate.

italian_milites.name: Lombard Gasindi
italian_milites.description: The Gasindi (Companions) were feudal vassals of the Lombard king. Because they served a similar role as the 'milites' (Latin for ''soldier''), it is possible that they were sometimes referred to as such, or that they served alongside such types of warriors. These vassals often fought on horseback, as had increasingly been the tradition and focus of the Lombards over the previous few hundred years. While the gasindi would evolve into the 'knights' of later periods, the Lombards are different from the Franks in that the Lombards had a longer history of fighting with the cavalry spear.

The WAB:AoA2 and Total War: ATTILA - Age of Charlemagne both messed up and used the term gastald/o to refer to warrior nobility at the rank of a knight or milites. Some wargaming miniature companies use this term instead and it's definition seems more appropriate.

hre_milites.name: Milites
hre_milites.description: By the twilight of the 10th Century, the Milites had transitioned to a greater use of the lance and shock tactics.

burgundian_milites.name: Burgundian Milites
burgundian_milites.description: The milites (Previously a Roman term for 'soldier) were a professional soldier class, who often fought on horseback, as had increasingly been the tradition and focus of the Franks over the previous few hundred years. While similar to the 'knights' of later periods, which this class would evolve into (Especially for the Normans), they focused less on the thrusting spear or lance, and more on the throwing spear and sword.

young_ministerialis.name: Young Ministerialis
young_ministerialis.description: The Ministerialis were unfree knights (warrior nobles), who according to the law had borrowed land from their lord and had to ask for permission to marry. In practice, they mostly behaved like free people, and often had multiple masters. As long as they remained available to serve and didn't serve their main lord's enemies, that was good enough.

ministerialis.name: Ministerialis
ministerialis.description: The Ministerialis were unfree knights (warrior nobles), who according to the law had borrowed land from their lord and had to ask for permission to marry. In practice, they mostly behaved like free people, and often had multiple masters. As long as they remained available to serve and didn't serve their main lord's enemies, that was good enough.

veteran_latest_pueri.name: Veteran Warrior Light cavalry
veteran_latest_pueri.description: With enough experiance, the light cavalry would become increasingly talented in the use of maneuver and ranged weapons.

models.name: Lowborn
models.notes: No idea if HRE should have this unit.

serjeants_crossbowmen.name: Serjeants Crossbowmen
serjeants_crossbowmen.description: During the period after Charlemagne, much of Western Europe (Not Britian) had grown used to seeing mounted warriors making the standard freeman levy 'obsolete'. They were replaced by 'serjeants' (Translates to 'Servent', but is a term used often for professonal, full-time soldiers), who due to being career mercenaries and having good pay, could build up experience and get better equipment.

mag_elite_steppe_nomad_archer.name: Magyar Mounted Archer
mag_elite_steppe_nomad_archer.description: Eastern Europe and Northwestern Asia (The Eurasian Steppe), were areas very supportive of horses and a nomaidic way of life. As such the area produced a wide range of expert horse archers. Such people could be Magyars, Khazars, Kazakhs, desendents of the Sarmatians, desendents of the Huns, or any number of other nomadic peoples within the area.

models.name: Magyar Tribesman
models.notes: (Quad LkI) WAB:GG. TtS, ALDG, WAB:FS:HRE suggest this unit should be here.

dux.name: Dux
dux.description: Dux, was a latin word meaning 'leader' or 'general'. The Dux made up the upper echelons of power in Germanic society, and the word would evolve into the familiar 'Duke'.

gastald.name: Gastaldo
gastald.description: Gastaldo (“stewards”), were paid officials with direct allegiance to the roving Lombard kings, a gastald was an official with civil, military, and judicial power over an urban area.

models.name: Gastald
models.notes: (Quad LkI) The WAB and Total War: ATTILA - Age of Charlemagne both messed up and thought this term referred to warrior nobility at the rank of a knight or milites. Instead, this term refers to something like a Comes/Count.

comes.name: Comes
comes.description: A Comes (plural, comites), was another latin word, like 'Dux'. This word meant 'companion', but increasingly among late Romans and 'Migration Era' Germanic peoples, meant 'military leader'. This word eventually evolved into the term 'count' and became a rank of nobility.

bishop.name: Bishop
bishop.description: As the Germanics christianized, Christianity (The Germanics were not always Catholic) became a center of their lives. The Church had access to so much wealth and lands, that some of its officals assembled their own armies and operated as warlords.

frank_bishop.name: Bishop
frank_bishop.description: As the Franks christianized, The Church became a center of their lives. This was passed down to the people of Burgundy. The Church had access to so much wealth and lands, that some of its officals assembled their own armies and operated as warlords.

priest.name: Christian Priest
priest.description: For the lives of rural living people, religion has always been at the center. During these dark and desperate times, for many in Europe, the Christian faith was the only hope they had.

fierce.name: Fierce
fierce.description_short: If an enemy unit in short distence (12') runs away or flees, this unit has to charge them. It gets +1 to melee when it does so
fierce.description: If an enemy unit in short distence (12') runs away or flees, this unit has to charge them. It gets +1 to melee when it does so
fierce.flavor: During the early Dark Ages, some units were exceptionally eager to 'run down' or 'run through' the enemy.

trample_them.name: Trample Them
trample_them.description: Whenever this unit does a group activation with a unit or uses 'Field Orders' on a unit, that unit gets 'superior_cavalry' for the rest of the round.

rex_italiae.name: Rex Italiae
rex_italiae.description: Unless the enemy is the 'Late Romans (400-500 AD)' or Early Byzantine Empire: this army can recruit or use any unit from the Late Romans (400-500 AD) faction.

rules.notes: These are redundant because my pushes are not being accepted and I need these rules to work for playtesting.

skirmisher_formation.name: Skirmisher Formation
skirmisher_formation.description_short: +1 Save to ranged hits at ranges further than 12', -1 Save to Melee
skirmisher_formation.description: +1 save against ranged attacks made at long range, -1 Save to Melee.
skirmisher_formation.flavor: This unit is part of a spread out formation, which means it can more easily dodge incoming missiles, but is more vunerable to being rushed by infantry.

vet_skirmisher_formation.name: Veteran Skirmishers
vet_skirmisher_formation.description_short: +1 Save to ranged hits at ranges further than 12', -1 Save to Melee
vet_skirmisher_formation.description: +1 save against ranged attacks made at long range, -1 Save to Melee, and +1 to Initiative for rushing.
vet_skirmisher_formation.flavor: This unit is part of a spread out formation, which means it can more easily dodge incoming missiles, but is more vunerable to being rushed by infantry.

light_infantry.name: Light Infantry
light_infantry.description: (This unit cannot use 'Spearmen' Rule) Optional: +1 save against ranged attacks made at long range, -1 Save to Melee.
light_infantry.flavor: This unit can choose to fight as skirmishers as a loose formation, or 'close up' to fight as traditional infantry.

light_cavalry.name: Light Cavalry
light_cavalry.description: Optional: +1 save against ranged attacks made at long range, -1 Save to Melee, and +1 to Initiative for rushing.
light_cavalry.flavor: This unit can choose to fight as skirmishers as a loose formation, or 'close up' to fight as medium cavalry.

man_of_god.name: Man of God
man_of_god.description: This unit can be merged with any other unit, that unit may re-roll any failed Courage test when removing Shock once per turn.

spearmen.name: Spearmen
spearmen.description: (Note: Requires unmounted, spear and shield) Should this unit do a 'Hold' action and be charged before it's next turn, it has +1 Strength when performing a Counter-Attack reaction and ignores 'Horseman Warrior Culture'.

pike.name: Pike
pike.description: Should this unit be charged, it has +1 Strength when performing a Counter-Attack reaction and it gets to attack first.

impale.name: Impale
impale.description: (Note: Requires horse or warhorse) This weapon gets +1 AP when used during a Charge.

joust.name: Joust
joust.description: (Note: Requires horse or warhorse) This weapon gets +2 AP when used during a Charge.

warrior_culture.name: Warrior Culture
warrior_culture.description: (Note: Requires attack with melee weapon without 'Reach') This unit gets a +1 Str during a Charge.

mount_warrior_culture.name: Horseman Warrior Culture
mount_warrior_culture.description: (Note: Requires melee weapon and Horse/War Horse) This unit gets a +1 Str during a Charge

furious_charge.name: Furious Charge
furious_charge.description_short: Charge and win, enemy unit breaks
furious_charge.description: (Requires War Horse) If this unit charges another and 'wins' the first round of combat, the other unit has to roll a break test. If the other unit has 'stubborn' rule, roll a d6, on a 1,2,or 3 the other unit avoids the break test.
furious_charge.flavor: The fury of heavy cavalry was terrifying to those not prepared for the loud pounding of hooves and for the sheer weight of the charge.

superior_cavalry.name: Superior Cavalry
superior_cavalry.description: (Requires Horse or War Horse) This unit may re-roll failed Strength tests when charging or making a Fight reaction (To a Charge).

otto.name: Otto, The Great
otto.flavor: Otto I, was not the start of his dynasty, but the he was the man who made the Holy Roman Empire what it became and is thought to be the first 'German' Emperor. Otto was a religious man, who showed that mounted archers were no longer the dominant force in Central Europe. Heavy Cavalry and 'Knights' would be the future
otto.description: Upgrade one Dux model with 'Trample Them'.

odoacer.name: Odoacer
odoacer.flavor: In terms of lineage, history only certain that Odacer was some type of German. Only year the Western Empire did not have enough land to pay their Foederati as well as the Legionaries, and did not have any land to spare them. Odoacer led the Barbarians in a revolt, defeated the Romans, won over The Senate, disbanded the Army, paid lip service to the Emperor in the East. He ruled as King of the Italy (Rex Italia) untill he was murdered during a diplomatic meeting.
odoacer.description: Upgrade one Dux model with 'Rex Italiae'.

strategies.name: Going Berserk
strategies.description: A selected unit gains +1 Strength till the end of the turn, but they can't use the turn to move away from the closest enemy.

strategies.name: Terrible Charge
strategies.description: One unit on foot gains the rule of 'furious_charge' till the end of the turn.

strategies.name: Swine's_Head
strategies.description: A selected unit gains +1 AP for all their melee weapons, during a charge.

strategies.name: Veterans
strategies.description: All units of geoguth may, once for the entire battle, choose to reroll all their dice to hit by shooting or melee. All dice must be rerolled, good or bad.
strategies.flavor: Many years of campaigning have given the Franks a pool of hardened veterans.

strategies.name: Hurry Hurry
strategies.description: Use after Cavalry makes or attempts a Rushing action. The unit reduces its Shock by one.

strategies.name: Run Them Down
strategies.description: Use when a Cavalry makes a Charge action. The Impact Rule gains +1 AP for the charge.

strategies.name: Shield Wall
strategies.description: Pick a unit of Infantry (with the 'Heavy_Infantry' Keyword) thas has shields and spears equipped (light infantry not included), if that unit moved one or no times this round, and if charged or targeted by a shooting attack it gets +1 Save and ignores the 'superior_cavalry' rule. This effect remains in place till the unit moves.

strategies.name: Bolster
strategies.description: Use when an Infantry unit is targeted by an enemy. If it did not move this round, that unit may increase its cover level by 1 (none to normal, normal to fortified).

strategies.name: My Home
strategies.description: Use when activating a unit with 'Militia' in it's name. That unit gets +1 Courage till the end of turn.

strategies.name: Triumpth of The Nobility
strategies.description: Select one Cavalry unit with 'light armor' or 'heavy armor', that unit has +1 to Saves against ranged attacks till the end of turn.
